name: zingiber-officinale
definition: Ginger  is a flowering plant whose rhizome, ginger root or ginger, is widely used as a spice and a folk medicine.
description:
Ginger is an erect, herbaceous perennial plant grown for its edible rhizome (underground stem) which is widely used as a spice.

It grows annual pseudostems (false stems made of the rolled bases of leaves) about one meter tall bearing narrow leaf blades.

The rhizome is brown, with a corky outer layer and pale-yellow scented center.

The above ground shoot is erect and reed-like with linear leaves that are arranged alternately on the stem.

The shoots originate from a multiple bases and wrap around one another.

The leaves can reach 7 centimeters in length and 1.9 centimeters broad.

Flowering heads are borne on shorter stems and the plant produces cone shaped, pale yellow flowers .

The ginger plant can reach 0.6 to 1.2 meters in height and is grown as an annual plant.

Ginger is a very popular spice, with a slightly biting taste, used worldwide.

Whether it be used to spice up meals, or as a medicine, the demand for ginger all over the world has been consistent throughout history.

Ginger can be used for a variety of food or medicine items such as vegetables, candy, soda, pickles, and alcoholic beverages.

Ginger is a fragrant kitchen spice.

Young ginger rhizomes are juicy and fleshy with a mild taste.

The peeled rhizomes may be preserved by boiling in syrup.

They are often pickled in vinegar or sherry as a snack or cooked as an ingredient in many dishes.

They can be steeped in boiling water to make ginger herb tea, to which honey may be added.

Ginger can be made into candy or ginger wine.

Ginger is used medically to treat flatulence and colic.

As a tropical plant, ginger grows best in warm and sunny climates in a deep but well draining soil loam that is high in organic matter.

The plant requires a minimum temperature of 15.5°C.

Ginger is vegetatively propagated from small sections of the rhizome, called sets.

Sets are produced by cutting a small part of 3 to 6 centimeters from a living rhizome.

Ginger originated in Island Southeast Asia and was likely domesticated first by the Austronesian peoples.

It was transported with them throughout the Indo-Pacific during the Austronesian expansion (about 3,000 BCE), reaching as far as Hawaii.

Ginger is one of the first spices to have been exported from Asia, arriving in Europe with the spice trade, and was used by ancient Greeks and Romans.

By the 11th century it was well known in England.

The Spaniards brought it to the West Indies and Mexico soon after the conquest, and by 1547 ginger was being exported from Santiago to Spain.

contextual.caption: Ginger plants require an average annual rainfall of between 250 and 300 centimeters, requiering additional irrigation where rainfall is not adequate.

featured.caption: The ginger inflorescences bear pale yellow with purple flowers and arise directly from the rhizome on separate shoots.

related.definition: Turmeric  is a flowering plant of the ginger family, the roots of which are used in cooking.
The parsnip  is a root vegetable closely related to carrot and parsley; all belong to the family Apiaceae.
